page_content='LXRP 
Christopher Mullan 
Ryan Thomas 

WPA 
James Crewe 
Ben Lolicato 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cEXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Introduction 

This  report  presents  the  findings  of  archaeological  investigations  conducted  under  Heritage  Victoria  issued 
Consent Numbers C1607, C1659 and C1703, by Andrew Long and Associates Pty Ltd (ALA) on behalf of the Level 
Crossing Removal Project (LXRP). Extensive ground disturbing works were required throughout  the Victorian 
Heritage  Inventory  site:  Former  North  Williamstown  Station  H7822-2389  to  facilitate  the  removal  of  the 
Ferguson Street, Williamstown level crossing and the construction of a new North Williamstown Station.  

Historical Background' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}

1.paragraph: The archaeological excavation site was located in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, specifically within the VHI site at Former North Williamstown Station.

was designated Area E (Map 5) and was subject to archaeological excavation as per the methodology 
in Former North Williamstown Station, Williamstown Consent Application: Supporting Documentation

page_content='21 

 
 
 
\x0c3  Archaeological Excavations  

3.1  Preamble 

This chapter outlines the aims, methods and results of the archaeological program undertaken within 
VHI site: Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389). 

3.2  Aims 

As per the conditions of Consents C1607, C1659 and C1703, the archaeological excavation program 
aimed  to  determine  the  integrity,  extent,  and  cultural  heritage  significance  of  the  Former  North 
Williamstown Station (H7822-2389), and any archaeological remains associated with the site, prior to 
the LXRP works. The archaeological excavation program aimed to record any archaeological remains 
prior to impacts from the construction works (see Section 1.3). 

3.3  Methodology' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}

page_content='Area A measured 18 m x 17 m and was located on the western side of the VHI site, to the north of 
Area  D  (Map  5). Test  Trench  6 was  initially  excavated  in  Area  A  under  C1607. This  resulted  in  the 
extension of the VHI site extent to incorporate historical features identified during the testing. Test 
trench 6 began as a narrow linear trench (approximately 0.6 m x 1 m) alongside the existing station 
building  in  order  to  assess  the  relationship  between the  historical  deposits  identified  in  other  test 
trenches and the station building. The identification of several unknown services required the trench 
to  be  moved  further  west,  away  from  the  building.  A  geotechnical  (GeoTech)  trench  was  also 
excavated during the archaeological testing program. The GeoTech trench was located slightly north 
of the original  VHI  site  extent;  however,  the  identification of  several  historical features  during  the' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}

2.paragraph: Example: The VHI provides protection to heritage sites in Victoria, Australia.
source:
page_content='Victorian Heritage Inventory 
The VHI exists under the Heritage Act 2017 and provides protection to places or objects identified as 
historical  archaeological  sites,  areas  or  relics  on  the  inventory,  as  well  as  all  known  areas  where 
artefacts are located or occur and any private collections which include archaeological artefacts. The 
Act provides blanket protection for all historical archaeological places in Victoria that are 75 years old 
or more. The VHI is a statutory listing of all known historical archaeological sites in Victoria, except for 
Commonwealth owned/managed places, which do not fall within the jurisdiction of Heritage Victoria. 
The VHI includes sites whose archaeological significance ranges from low to high, including places with 
archaeological potential.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}

page_content='7.1.1  Recommendations   

1.  ALA recommends the extent of the VHI site Former North Williamstown Station H7822-2389 
is reduced to reflect the portions of the site which retain archaeological potential (Area D and 
the extant upside station building) following completion of the archaeological investigations 
and construction works endorsed under C1609, C1659 and C1703. The proposed revised site 
extent is presented in Map 6. 

2.  ALA recommends further archaeological excavation within the revised VHI site extent prior to 

any future impacts to the site. 

3.  ALA recommends the conservation treatment of the artefact assemblage be completed within 

6 months of the submission of this report. 

4.  Following  the  completion of conservation  treatments  the  retained  portions of the  artefact 
assemblage will be lodged at HVs artefact repository, and the remainder of the assemblage 
will be discarded.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}

page_content='xii 

 
 
  
 
 
\x0c1  Introduction 

1.1  Preamble 

This report presents the results of recent archaeological investigations at Former North Williamstown 
Station (H7822-2389) conducted under Heritage Victoria Consents C1607, C1659 and C1703. Andrew 
Long and Associates Pty Ltd (ALA) was engaged to undertake these investigations by Western Program 
Alliance  (WPA) on behalf of the Level Crossing  Removal Project (LXRP).  The LXRP works within the 
Victorian Heritage Inventory (VHI) site Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) pertain to 
the removal of a level crossing on the Williamstown Railway line at Ferguson Street, Williamstown. 
LXRP  lowered  the  Williamstown  Railway  line  under Ferguson  Street;  therefore,  removing the  level 
crossing. The LXRP works required impacts to the majority of the VHI site.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5210_Former North Williamstown Station (H7822-2389) - Final Excavation Report.pdf'}
